text: Modulation of normal erythroid differentiation by the endogenous thyroid hormone and retinoic acid receptors : a possible target for <extra_id_0> v-erbA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> oncogene action .

The <extra_id_0> v-erbA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> oncogene , a mutated version of the <extra_id_0> thyroid hormone receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> c-erbA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> TR-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , inhibits erythroid differentiation and constitutively represses transcription of certain erythrocyte genes , suggesting a normal function of the proto-oncogene <extra_id_0> c-erbA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in erythropoiesis .

Here we demonstrate that the endogenous <extra_id_0> thyroid hormone receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> c-erbA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> TR-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and the closely related <extra_id_0> retinoic acid receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RAR-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) play a role in the regulation of normal erythroid differentiation .
Retinoic acid ( RA ) distinctly modulated the erythroid differentiation program of normal erythroid progenitors and erythroblasts reversibly transformed by a conditional tyrosine kinase oncogene .
When added pulsewise to immature cells , differentiation was accelerated while more mature cells underwent premature cell death .
Thyroid hormone ( T3 ) alone caused similar but weaker effects .
Interestingly , T3 strongly enhanced the action of RA , suggesting cooperative action of the two receptors in modulating erythroid differentiation .

Expression of the human <extra_id_0> RAR-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in receptor - negative erythroblasts conferred RA - induced regulation of differentiation to the otherwise unresponsive cells , thus showing that the <extra_id_0> RAR-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is essential for the RA effect .

Likewise , enhanced expression of exogenous <extra_id_0> c-erbA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> TR-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in erythroblasts rendered them susceptible to modulation of differentiation by T3 , suggesting a similar function of both receptors .
